articles.headline: ‘Superstar Firms’ May Have Shrunk Workers’ Share of Income
articles.snippet: It was long Keynesian dogma that two-thirds of economic output goes to labor. That truism has come undone, and corporate consolidation may be a cause.
articles.abstract: It was long Keynesian dogma that two-thirds of economic output goes to labor. That truism has come undone, and corporate consolidation may be a cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last century it seemed that the slice of the total economic pie going to workers was — like the speed of light — constant. No matter what the economy’s makeup, labor could collectively depend on taking home roughly two-thirds of the country’s total output as compensation for its efforts. Workers’ unchanging share, the economist John Maynard Keynes declared in 1939, was “one of the most surprising, yet best-established, facts in the whole range of economic statistics.”

articles.headline: Health Groups Denounce G.O.P. Bill as Its Backers Scramble
articles.snippet: Influential medical groups warned that the plan would lead to a rise in the uninsured, leaving House Republicans scrambling to marshal support.
articles.abstract: Influential medical groups warned that the plan would lead to a rise in the uninsured, leaving House Republicans scrambling to marshal support.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Influential groups representing hospitals and nurses came out on Wednesday against a Republican bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, joining doctors and the retirees’ lobby to warn that it would lead to a rise in the uninsured.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough, Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: As Dubai’s Skyline Adds a Trophy, the Architect Calls It Stolen
articles.snippet: The designer of a new landmark building is suing over copyright infringement, describing an entrenched system where power can trump sanctity of law.
articles.abstract: The designer of a new landmark building is suing over copyright infringement, describing an entrenched system where power can trump sanctity of law.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Few cities on earth can compete with Dubai for sheer verticality. The pale sands of this once forgettable port alongside the emptiness of the Arabian desert have proved fertile ground for all manner of skyscrapers.

articles.headline: Russia’s RT Network: Is It More BBC or K.G.B.?
articles.snippet: Analysts say the network is spreading disinformation and undermining Western democracies, but its executives say it is just providing an “alternative” view.
articles.abstract: Analysts say the network is spreading disinformation and undermining Western democracies, but its executives say it is just providing an “alternative” view.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London newsroom and studios of RT, the television channel and website formerly known as Russia Today, are ultramodern and spacious, with spectacular views from the 16th floor overlooking the Thames and the London Eye. And, its London bureau chief, Nikolay A. Bogachikhin, jokes, “We overlook MI5 and we’re near MI6,” Britain’s domestic and foreign intelligence agencies.

articles.headline: Fox Is Said to Settle With Former Contributor Over Sexual Assault Claims
articles.snippet: The company, still dealing with the fallout from the harassment scandal involving Roger Ailes, has reached a settlement for more than $2.5 million with Tamara Holder, who said an executive assaulted her.
articles.abstract: The company, still dealing with the fallout from the harassment scandal involving Roger Ailes, has reached a settlement for more than $2.5 million with Tamara Holder, who said an executive assaulted her.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, as it wrapped up multiple settlements after the Roger Ailes sexual harassment scandal, Fox News and its parent company, 21st Century Fox, were trying hard to end the ugliest chapter in its 20-year history.

articles.headline: Uber Seeks to Prevent Use of Greyball to Thwart Regulators
articles.snippet: In the wake of a New York Times article about the tool, which appeared to allow drivers to avoid officers in Oregon, the company said it was conducting a review of how it is used.
articles.abstract: In the wake of a New York Times article about the tool, which appeared to allow drivers to avoid officers in Oregon, the company said it was conducting a review of how it is used.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The ride-hailing service Uber said on Wednesday that it would prohibit employees from using a program called Greyball to thwart regulators.

articles.headline: As E.C.B. Charts Economic Course, Politics Complicate the Picture
articles.snippet: The central bank’s president, Mario Draghi, is under increasing pressure to ease stimulus measures, a difficult task in a charged political atmosphere.
articles.abstract: The central bank’s president, Mario Draghi, is under increasing pressure to ease stimulus measures, a difficult task in a charged political atmosphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Central bankers like to portray themselves as being aloof from the hurly-burly of politics, coolly assessing the economic data as they ponder whether to add a jolt of stimulus or take some away.

articles.headline: After Halting Start, Trump Plunges Into Effort to Repeal Health Law
articles.snippet: The president is marshaling the full power of his office to woo Republicans, disarm conservatives and win passage of a bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: The president is marshaling the full power of his office to woo Republicans, disarm conservatives and win passage of a bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, after a halting start, is now marshaling the full power of his office to win over holdout conservatives and waffling senators to support the House Republicans’ replacement for the Affordable Care Act.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Robert Pear

articles.headline: A.I.G.’s Chief Executive to Resign After Turnaround Setback
articles.snippet: The move by the insurer follows a big fourth-quarter loss and pressure by investors including Carl Icahn.
articles.abstract: The move by the insurer follows a big fourth-quarter loss and pressure by investors including Carl Icahn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly nine years after the insurance giant American International Group peered into the abyss of the global financial crisis, the latest in a long line of new chief executives will try to return it to its pre-crisis heights.
